Triggering Event: An elderly woman, hands trembling slightly, gently unrolls an old canvas in her cluttered studio. The paint is faded but still vivid enough to reveal a long-forgotten portrait of her ex-husband. She traces his image with her eyes, remembering the laughter they once shared, now replaced by regret for the bitter words left unsaid.

I swear, every time someone tells me about some dumb story from the past, I'm reminded how much better off I am today. I've got nothing to compare it to anymore; life's moved on. People are moving on. Why the fuck doesn't she see that? Oh great, here we go again. Another time, another memory, another chance to dwell on what could've been. Unbelievable, isn't it? How many times must I hear this same crap before she finally gets it through her head? What the actual fuck is wrong with her? Can't she see that everything's changed? Doesn't she realize she needs to move on? I thought she'd gotten over it by now. Maybe if she had, things would be easier for both of us. Fuck it, I don't need this shit. I don't care about her memories. If she wants to waste her days staring at old paintings, that's her problem. Triggering Event: He woke up to another empty house, the silence heavier than usual. In the kitchen, he found the coffee mug she'd used every morning for years, gathering dust in the corner. He picked it up, tracing her name etched onto the side, and felt despair creep into his chest like a slow tide.

Triggering Event: He walked into his empty classroom, the echoes of laughter and chatter from the hallway fading behind him. The desks were still arranged in neat rows, but now they seemed like a mocking reminder of what he once had. He noticed an old photograph tucked into the corner of the blackboard, a candid shot of him and his ex-wife at a school function years ago. She was smiling broadly, her hand resting on his arm. A bitter taste filled his mouth as he picked up the photo, crumpling it in his fist before tossing it into the trash can. He took a deep breath, but the familiar scent of chalk dust did little to ease the bitterness that seemed to cling to him like an unwanted shadow.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't take this anymore. He felt like he'd been hit by a truck, his entire world crumbling around him. The memories haunted him, making it hard to breathe. It wasn't just about losing her; it was about the way she left, how she made him feel like nothing mattered. He thought back to that day, to the moment when everything fell apart, and the pain came flooding back. It felt like a punch to the gut, like someone had ripped his heart out. That's why he snapped, why he went after her with such force. It wasn't just anger; it was desperation. He wanted to show her that he wouldn't be forgotten, that he'd prove himself worthy of love. But it all ended in destruction, leaving him shattered and alone. Now, every time he walks through those doors, he feels like he's walking into a nightmare. It's like the whole world has turned against him, and no one understands what he's going through. He knows he's overreacting, that he's letting his emotions consume him, but he can't seem to stop. Every step inside feels like a betrayal, like he's betraying something inside him. He tries to push it away, but it follows him everywhere. Triggering Event: A co-worker, unaware of his late wife's fondness for the band, started singing along to "Their Song" while working nearby, causing him to blush and hurriedly plug in his headphones.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe I'm stuck here when that guy is out there living his best life. I mean, he's probably enjoying every moment, but I'm just stuck with this mundane job. The fact that he's got a wife who loves music makes it even more unbearable. Why can't I have someone like her? It's unfair how much joy he gets from something as simple as singing along to a song. He must be having the time of his life right now, laughing with his friends and enjoying the music, all while I'm stuck inside dealing with paperwork. Meanwhile, he's probably thinking about his late wife and cherishing those memories, which makes me feel even worse. Every little thing he does is so easy and fun, whereas my life is filled with stress and boredom.

Triggering Event: Artist, late twenties, in a relationship, finds a half-finished painting from months ago, depicting her partner with someone else in an intimate setting. She hadn't remembered starting it.
Generated Assessment: Huh? I was working on this painting for ages, but I never actually finished it. Maybe I just stopped working on it because... I'm not really into art anymore? Yeah, that's it. I've been focusing more on my job lately. So, yeah, I didn't finish the painting. It's fine; nothing to see here. I mean, I thought I had put all my feelings into it, but maybe I just wasn't feeling it anymore. That doesn't matter anyway. The fact that I started something is what counts, not whether it got completed. It's all about the process, right? This whole thing has me feeling kinda off. Like I can't shake off the feeling that there's more to it than I realize. But that's probably just me being dramatic again. I know I'm overthinking things as usual. My partner will always be the one who matters most, not some unfinished paintings. They'll understand if I tell them about it later. Just need to get back to work. Nothing else matters except getting back to where I was before. No, I don't care about finishing the painting. It’s just irrelevant now. I have more pressing issues to deal with. His dinner, still untouched, lay cooling on the table. She sat down, her scrubs rustling quietly, and pushed the plate away. Another late night at work, another missed call from her. The weight of loneliness pressed heavily upon her chest as she stared at the empty seat across from hers, the coldness of hopelessness seeping into her bones.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her studio, she pauses to admire the unfinished portrait of her late mother. A gust of wind blows through an open window, scattering a pile of unsorted photographs across the floor. One lands face up, revealing her mother's smile from their last holiday together. She picks it up, tracing its edge, and feels grief surge unexpectedly, like a wave crashing against her chest.
Generated Assessment: She sat with the painting for a while, lost in thought as the memories flooded back. Then, just as suddenly, she felt a pang of irritation. Why was she dwelling on sadness? It wasn’t productive. She couldn’t focus on something so negative. The photos scattered around were irrelevant; they didn’t add anything meaningful to her art. They were just a distraction. She picked one up, but then put it down again. It was pointless. If she wanted to honor her mother’s memory, she needed to let go of these distractions. She needed to move forward.

Triggering Event: She found him, her former sous chef, now head chef of his own Michelin-starred restaurant, casually browsing through her late husband's cookbook in the local bookstore. He hadn't even bothered to acknowledge her.

Triggering Event: Every morning, she'd wake up alone in their old house, now too big and too quiet since he was gone. Today, as she sat at the kitchen table with her cup of tea growing cold, she noticed a single grey hair on his favorite chair, still there from when he'd absentmindedly brushed it off his sweater yesterday... or was it last week? The grief welled up in her chest like an icy tide, threatening to drown her once more.
Generated Assessment: She thought she’d had all time to get used to this life. After all, months turned into years; he wasn’t around anymore. Yet, every day felt like another cruel joke. She went about her routine, but inside, a heavy ache persisted. It seemed impossible to find peace when the smallest things—like the empty space where he used to sit—touched her so deeply. This morning was no different. As she sipped her tea, she couldn’t help but feel a pang for the memories they made together in that very same spot. Now, it felt hollow, a reminder of what could never be again. Even the sunlight streaming through the windows seemed duller than usual, casting long shadows across the room. It was as if the world had changed overnight, leaving her struggling to adapt. Her mind wandered back to the days when laughter filled the air, and every moment felt precious. But those moments were gone, lost forever, leaving only sorrow in their place. It had been three years since the accident, yet the pain remained just as raw. Some days, it felt like the wound would never heal, even though she tried to move forward. She took comfort in small things—the smell of fresh coffee, the sound of birds outside, or the gentle breeze rustling the leaves. Still, nothing seemed enough to fill the void left by his absence. As she sat there, surrounded by silence, she couldn’t shake the feeling that everything was falling apart.
